data.title: Wet Tropics of Queensland
data.text: The Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Site consists of approximately 8 940 km2 of Australian wet tropical forests growing along the north east Queensland portion of the Great Dividing Range The Wet Tropics of Queensland meets all four of the criteria for natural heritage for selection as a World Heritage Site World Heritage status was declared in 1988 and on 21 May 2007 the Wet Tropics were added to the Australian National Heritage List The tropical forests have the highest concentration of primitive flowering plant families in the world Only Madagascar and New Caledonia due to their historical isolation have humid tropical regions with a comparable level of endemism
